1.label: parent
1.description: He was married twice, and had three sons, two, Ivan and Alexey, by his second.

1.label: parent
1.description: He was married twice, and had three sons, two, Ivan and Alexey, by his second.

1.label: sibling
1.description: Ivan is one of the two sons by Fyodor Pavlovitch’s second wife, and Alexey is the other.

2.label: spouse
2.description: Adelaida Ivanovna discerned in a flash that she had no feeling for her husband but contempt.

2.label: spouse
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch got hold of all her money up to twenty‐five thousand roubles as soon as she received it.

2.label: parent
2.description: Leaving Mitya, a child of three years old, in her husband’s hands.

2.label: parent
2.description: Leaving Mitya, a child of three years old, in her husband’s hands.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: Finally, she left the house and ran away from Fyodor Pavlovitch with a destitute divinity student.

3.label: spouse
3.description: At last he succeeded in getting on the track of his runaway wife.

3.label: spouse
3.description: She had died quite suddenly in a garret...

0.label: father
0.description: He completely abandoned the child of his marriage with Adelaida Ivanovna, not from malice, nor because of his matrimonial grievances, but simply because he forgot him.

0.label: caretaker
0.description: If he hadn't looked after him there would have been no one even to change the baby's little shirt.

0.label: spouse
0.description: the child of his marriage with Adelaida Ivanovna

1.label: father
1.description: ...if his father had remembered him...

1.description: ...hearing all about Adelaida Ivanovna, whom he, of course, remembered...

1.label: guardian
1.description: ...he wished to undertake the child's education...

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: ...made the latter's acquaintance for the first time...

1.label: relative
1.description: ...whom he...had at one time been interested...

2.label: guardian
2.description: Pyotr Alexandrovitch carried the business through vigorously, and was appointed, with Fyodor Pavlovitch, joint guardian of the child...

2.label: guardian
2.description: Pyotr Alexandrovitch carried the business through vigorously, and was appointed, with Fyodor Pavlovitch, joint guardian of the child...

2.label: ward
2.description: he left the boy in charge of one of his cousins, a lady living in Moscow.

2.label: guardian
2.description: ...Mitya passed into the care of one of her married daughters.

2.label: guardian
2.description: ...Mitya passed into the care of one of her married daughters.

3.label: child
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch is the son of Fyodor Pavlovitch, as indicated by the phrase "the only one of Fyodor Pavlovitch’s three sons..."

3.label: parent
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch is the father of Dmitri Fyodorovitch, as indicated by the phrase "the whole value of his property in sums of money from Fyodor Pavlovitch..."

0.label: spouse
0.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch married a second time... His second marriage lasted eight years.

0.label: spouse
0.description: ...the poor child exchanged a benefactress for a benefactor.

0.label: benefactor
0.description: ...grew up in the house of a general’s widow, a wealthy old lady of good position, who was at once her benefactress and tormentor.

0.label: torturer
0.description: ...was once cut down from a halter in which she was hanging from a nail in the loft, so terrible were her sufferings from the caprice and everlasting nagging of this old woman...

0.label: rival
0.description: ...Fyodor Pavlovitch did not get a penny this time, for the general’s widow was furious. She gave them nothing and cursed them both.

1.label: spouse
1.description: As he had received no dowry with his wife, and had, so to speak, taken her 'from the halter.'

1.label: parent
1.description: In the end this unhappy young woman, kept in terror from her childhood, fell into that kind of nervous disease... Yet she bore Fyodor Pavlovitch two sons, Ivan and Alexey.

1.label: parent
1.description: Yet she bore Fyodor Pavlovitch two sons, Ivan and Alexey, the eldest in the first year of marriage and the second three years later.

1.label: sibling
1.description: In the end this unhappy young woman, kept in terror from her childhood, fell into that kind of nervous disease... Yet she bore Fyodor Pavlovitch two sons, Ivan and Alexey.

1.label: sibling
1.description: Yet she bore Fyodor Pavlovitch two sons, Ivan and Alexey, the eldest in the first year of marriage and the second three years later.

1.label: servant-master
1.description: Grigory, the gloomy, stupid, obstinate, argumentative servant, who had always hated his first mistress, Adelaida Ivanovna, took the side of his new mistress.

1.label: servant-master
1.description: He championed her cause, abusing Fyodor Pavlovitch in a manner little befitting a servant.

1.label: rival
1.description: Grigory, the gloomy, stupid, obstinate, argumentative servant, who had always hated his first mistress, Adelaida Ivanovna, took the side of his new mistress.

1.label: parent-child
1.description: She was still alive, and had not, all those eight years, forgotten the insult done her.

1.label: grandparent-grandchild
1.description: She was still alive, and had not, all those eight years, forgotten the insult done her while obtaining exact information as to her Sofya's manner of life.

1.label: grandparent-grandchild
1.description: She was still alive, and had not, all those eight years, forgotten the insult done her while obtaining exact information as to her Sofya's manner of life.

2.label: other
2.description: The General's widow came straight to Fyodor Pavlovitch's house and gave him two resounding slaps on the face upon seeing him.

2.label: other
2.description: Seeing the children unwashed and in dirty linen, she promptly gave Grigory a box on the ear.

2.label: other
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch did not refuse the General's widow his formal consent to any proposition in regard to his children's education.

2.label: other
2.description: Grigory accepted the blow like a devoted slave and made her a low bow, stating that 'God would repay her for the orphans.'

3.label: guardian
3.description: Yefim Petrovitch took a personal interest in the orphans. He became especially fond of the younger, Alexey, who lived for a long while as one of his family.

3.label: guardian
3.description: To Yefim Petrovitch, a man of a generosity and humanity rarely to be met with, the young people were more indebted for their education and bringing up than to any one.

3.label: father-son
3.description: Ivan had realized that they were living not in their own home but on other people’s charity, and that their father was a man of whom it was disgraceful to speak.

3.label: father-son
3.description: Ivan had realized that they were living not in their own home but on other people’s charity, and that their father was a man of whom it was disgraceful to speak.

3.label: benefactor
3.description: Ivan used to declare afterwards that this was all due to the “ardor for good works” of Yefim Petrovitch, who was captivated by the idea that the boy’s genius should be trained by a teacher of genius.

4.label: father-son
4.description: ...that a young man so learned, so proud, and apparently so cautious, should suddenly visit such an infamous house and a father who had ignored him all his life...

4.label: brothers
4.description: ...that Ivan had come partly at the request of, and in the interests of, his elder brother, Dmitri, whom he saw for the first time on this very visit...

4.label: father-son
4.description: ...the young man had an unmistakable influence over his father, who positively appeared to be behaving more decently...

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: ...when he made the acquaintance of the young man, who interested him extremely...

5.label: sibling
5.description: Ivan appeared at the time in the light of a mediator between his father and his elder brother Dmitri, who was in open quarrel with his father.

5.label: parent-child
5.description: Ivan appeared at the time in the light of a mediator between his father and his elder brother Dmitri, who was in open quarrel with his father.

5.label: parent-child
5.description: Dmitri, who was in open quarrel with his father and even planning to bring an action against him.

5.label: sibling
5.description: The younger brother, Alexey, had been a year already among us, having been the first of the three to arrive.

5.label: sibling
5.description: The younger brother, Alexey, had been a year already among us, having been the first of the three to arrive.

0.label: brother
0.description: Alyosha is mentioned as having an older brother Ivan who is in his twenty-fourth year.

0.label: brother
0.description: Alyosha is mentioned as having an older brother Dmitri who is twenty-seven.

0.label: mother
0.description: Alyosha lost his mother at the age of four but remembered her vividly and fondly throughout his life.

0.label: spiritual mentor
0.description: Alyosha became attached to Elder Zossima, finding in him the ideal escape for his soul.

0.label: father
0.description: Alyosha's father is mentioned as having a troubled disposition towards Alyosha at first.

0.label: father-son
0.description: Alyosha's father expresses distrust initially but later embraces him with affection.

1.label: patron/benefactor
1.description: When Alyosha Karamazov entered the household of his patron and benefactor, Yefim Petrovitch Polenov, he gained the hearts of all the family.

2.label: benefactor
2.description: Alyosha lived at the expense of Yefim Petrovitch as indicated by the line: 'Alyosha went to live in the house of two distant relations of Yefim Petrovitch.'

2.label: relative
2.description: The widow is part of Yefim Petrovitch's family to which Alyosha was connected after his death: 'The inconsolable widow went almost immediately after his death for a long visit to Italy with her whole family.'

2.label: brothers
2.description: Alyosha is presented as a contrast to his elder brother Ivan: 'Alyosha was a striking contrast to his elder brother Ivan, who struggled with poverty.'

2.label: brothers
2.description: The relationship as brothers is highlighted in the context comparing their approaches to their circumstances.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: After getting to know Alyosha, Miusov expressed a judgment about him: 'Here is perhaps the one man in the world whom you might leave alone without a penny.'

3.label: father
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch could not show him where his second wife was buried, for he had never visited her grave since he had thrown earth upon her coffin, and in the course of years had entirely forgotten where she was buried.

3.label: child to deceased parent
3.description: It soon became apparent that he was looking for his mother’s tomb.

3.label: benefactors
3.description: The ladies provided him liberally with money and even fitted him out with new clothes and linen.

character_mapping.Unnamed Ladies: Grushenka, Katerina Ivanovna, and other noblewomen

4.label: servant
4.description: Grigory, who by that time had aged considerably too, and used to look after Fyodor Pavlovitch sometimes almost like a tutor.

4.label: son
4.description: Alyosha’s arrival seemed to affect even his moral side, as though something had awakened in this prematurely old man which had long been dead in his soul.

5.label: guardian
5.description: Grigory often refers to Alyosha in connection with his deceased mother, indicating a sense of guardianship or care.

5.label: employer
5.description: Grigory often pestered Fyodor Pavlovitch about the grave, showing their working relationship.

5.label: son
5.description: Alyosha is mentioned as the son of the 'crazy woman,' also tying him to Fyodor Pavlovitch in a familial context.

5.label: former spouse
5.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch mentions the first wife, Adelaida Ivanovna, who used to thrash him, indicating a relationship of marriage.

6.label: father
6.description: Alyosha suddenly announced that he wanted to enter the monastery, and that he was solemnly asking his consent as his father.

6.label: father
6.description: The old man knew that the elder Zossima, who was living in the monastery hermitage, had made a special impression upon his 'gentle boy.'

7.label: friendship
7.description: "I’ve really grown fond of you? Well, it’s a good opportunity. You’ll pray for us sinners; we have sinned too much here."

8.label: child
8.description: Alyosha looks gently and seriously at his father, indicating a son-father relationship.

8.label: parent
8.description: The phrase 'I feel that you’re the only creature in the world who has not condemned me' indicates a father-son bond.

0.label: influencer
0.description: Alyosha's thoughts about belief and miracles highlight a comparison with the Apostle Thomas's approach to faith.

1.label: theistic belief
1.description: As soon as Alyosha Karamazov reflected seriously he was convinced of the existence of God.

2.label: mother-son
2.description: Alyosha's memories of childhood brought back our monastery, to which his mother may have taken him to mass.

2.label: mentor-student
2.description: In the monastery he met this elder, which indicates a relationship of guidance or learning.

2.label: teacher-disciple
2.description: Paissy Velitchkovsky is mentioned as one of the great 'ascetics' who revived the institution of elders, influencing those who came after him, like Zossima.

4.label: Obedience
4.description: The monk was commanded by his elder to quit Athos, which he loved as a sacred place...

4.label: Authority
4.description: The monk... besought the Œcumenical Patriarch at Constantinople to release him from his obedience.

4.label: Respect/Authority
4.description: The Patriarch replied that... there was not and could not be on earth a power which could release him except the elder...

5.label: relationship type
5.description: Alyosha lived in the cell of the elder, who was very fond of him and let him wait upon him.

6.label: admirer
6.description: Alyosha had unquestioning faith in the miraculous power of the elder, just as he had unquestioning faith in the story of the coffin that flew out of the church.

6.label: mentor
6.description: The majority were on Father Zossima’s side and very many of them loved him with all their hearts, warmly and sincerely.

6.label: follower
6.description: Some were almost fanatically devoted to him, and declared, though not quite aloud, that he was a saint.

character_mapping.the monks: the monks of the Skete and the monastery

7.label: admiration
7.description: Alyosha fully believed in the spiritual power of his teacher and rejoiced in his fame, in his glory, as though it were his own triumph.

8.label: sibling
8.description: The arrival of his two brothers, whom he had not known till then, seemed to make a great impression on Alyosha. He more quickly made friends with his half‐brother Dmitri.

8.label: sibling
8.description: The arrival of his two brothers... seemed to make a great impression on Alyosha... he was extremely interested in his brother Ivan.

8.label: sibling
8.description: Dmitri used to speak of Ivan with the deepest respect and with a peculiar earnestness.

9.label: father
9.description: The discord between Dmitri and his father seemed at its acutest stage and their relations had become insufferably strained.

9.label: son
9.description: Dmitri, who had never seen the elder, naturally supposed that his father was trying to intimidate him.

9.label: son
9.description: He had such an extraordinary influence on Alyosha.

9.label: brother
9.description: He had such an extraordinary influence on Alyosha in relation to Dmitri.

9.label: acquaintance
9.description: A Liberal of the forties and fifties, a freethinker and atheist, he may have been led on by boredom or the hope of frivolous diversion... seized with the desire to see the monastery and the holy man.

9.label: mentor/influence
9.description: Who has made me a judge over them? was all he said, smilingly, to Alyosha.

10.label: brother
10.description: Alyosha sent word the day before, through a friend, to his brother Dmitri, that he loved him and expected him to keep his promise.

10.label: brother
10.description: Although Alyosha is worried about Ivan's supercilious half-utterances during the meeting with the elder.

10.label: acquaintance
10.description: Alyosha dreaded any affront to the elder, especially the refined, courteous irony of Miusov.

10.label: brother
10.description: Dmitri received word from Alyosha, showing that they communicate and care about each other.

10.label: brother
10.description: Though Dmitri expresses respect for the elder and his brother Ivan, he also fears that the meeting is a trap.

0.label: guardian/relative
0.description: Miusov was trying to persuade Pyotr Fomitch Kalganov to go abroad to the university of Zurich or Jena, as he was staying with him for the time.

0.label: friend
0.description: Pyotr Fomitch Kalganov was a friend of Alyosha's.

1.label: parent-child
1.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch is accompanied by his son Ivan.

1.label: sibling
1.description: Dmitri is mentioned as being late, but with no specific remark on his relationship to Fyodor Pavlovitch.

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: Miusov is present among the visitors and seems knowledgeable about the context needing assistance.

1.label: benevolent act
1.description: Kalganov gives a ten-copeck piece to an old woman, saying: 'Divide it equally.'

1.label: fellow visitors
1.description: Miusov notes the presence of other individuals of higher rank among the worshippers.

1.label: acquaintance
1.description: Maximov introduces himself to the visitors, indicating familiarity with their situation.

2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch expresses delight at being invited to dine with the Father Superior, indicating a relationship of acquaintance with Miusov as they discuss their visit and custom.

2.label: son
2.description: Miusov comments on Dmitri Fyodorovitch as non-existent as yet, indicating a father-son relationship since Fyodor Pavlovitch would be Dmitri's father.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Miusov expresses disdain for Fyodor Pavlovitch's company, showing an acquaintance relationship.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Maximov declares he has been already to the elder, attempting to engage Fyodor Pavlovitch's interest, indicating an acquaintance.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Maximov's incoherent talk about the elder Zossima was cut short by Miusov's authoritative statement, indicating an acquaintance.

2.label: official relationship
2.description: The monk announces the invitation from the Father Superior, demonstrating an official relationship within the context of the monastery.

2.label: official relationship
2.description: The monk invites Miusov to dine with the Father Superior, showing the formal relationship as a monk serving at the monastery.

2.label: official relationship
2.description: The monk includes Maximov in the invitation from the Father Superior, indicating an official relationship.

3.label: other
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch speaks to the monk and tries to engage in humor, hinting at their interaction at the hermitage.

3.label: other
3.description: The monk retains a sense of dignity despite Fyodor Pavlovitch's provocations.

3.label: other
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch is associated with Miusov in their visit to the hermitage.

3.label: other
3.description: Miusov warns Fyodor Pavlovitch about his behavior at the hermitage, suggesting an uneasy association.

3.label: parent-child
3.description: The context implies that Madame Hohlakov is waiting with her sick daughter for the elder.

4.label: antagonistic relationship
4.description: ...if you will wait a minute I will announce you. ... I am annoyed, I shall lose my temper and begin to quarrel—and lower myself and my ideas...

4.label: irritated relationship
4.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch observed sarcastically... Are you uneasy about your sins?

0.label: guardian/mentor
0.description: Father Zossima was accompanied by a novice, and by Alyosha.

0.label: student/mentor
0.description: Alyosha's reverence and presence with Father Zossima imply a student-mentor relationship.

0.label: guest/monk
0.description: Miusov fancies that the ceremony was done with intentional impressiveness during the elder's blessing.

0.label: guest/guest
0.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch mimicked Miusov like an ape, showing their interaction during the visit.

0.label: guest/monk
0.description: Ivan bowed with great dignity and courtesy to the elder, indicating respect as a guest.

0.label: guest/monk
0.description: Kalganov was so confused that he did not bow at all when greeted by the elder, indicating his status as a guest.

1.label: dissatisfaction
1.description: Miusov took a cursory glance at all these 'conventional' surroundings and bent an intent look upon the elder. At the first moment he did not like Zossima.

1.label: opinion
1.description: He had a high opinion of his own insight, a weakness excusable in him as he was fifty.

1.label: perception
1.description: To all appearances a malicious soul, full of petty pride, thought Miusov.

character_mapping.Father Zossima: Father Zossima, also known as Zossima Fyodorovich

character_mapping.Miusov: Miusov, full name typically referenced as Mikhail Ivanovich Miusov

2.label: parent
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch says, 'But no sign of my son, Dmitri.'

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch addresses Alyosha as 'sacred elder.'

2.label: antagonist
2.description: Miusov mutters, 'But you are not a king, anyway,' losing his self-restraint at Fyodor Pavlovitch's words.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch addresses Pyotr Alexandrovitch directly.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch recounts a story where he said to an influential person: 'Your wife is a ticklish lady.'

3.label: other
3.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch interacts with Pyotr Alexandrovitch, expressing his thoughts and engaging in a conversation, revealing his nature as a buffoon and sharing anecdotes.

3.label: other
3.description: Miusov expresses irritation toward Fyodor Pavlovitch for telling lies and playing the fool, indicating a conflict or disagreement in their relationship.

3.label: other
3.description: Pyotr Alexandrovitch is addressed directly by Fyodor Pavlovitch, illustrating a dynamic of criticism and engagement in discussion.

4.label: guest
4.description: Miusov addressed Father Zossima, indicating that he seemed to be taking part in a visit to an honored personage.

4.label: other
4.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch suddenly calls out to Father Zossima, suggesting a curious and somewhat antagonistic attitude toward him.

4.label: brother
4.description: Alyosha stood on the verge of tears regarding his brother Ivan's indifference during the visit.

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: Alyosha does not dare to look at Rakitin, whom he knows almost intimately, indicating a familiarity.

4.label: father and son
4.description: Ivan had influence on his father Fyodor Pavlovitch and could have stopped him, indicating a familial relationship.

5.label: spiritual advisor
5.description: The Elder advised the Buffoon, saying, 'Do not trouble. Make yourself quite at home. And, above all, do not be so ashamed of yourself, for that is at the root of it all.'

5.label: seeking guidance
5.description: The Buffoon asked Father Zossima, 'what must I do to gain eternal life?'.

5.label: mentor
5.description: Father Zossima provided moral advice to the Buffoon, stating, 'You have known for a long time what you must do.'

6.label: other
6.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch skips up, and imprints a rapid kiss on the elder’s thin hand.

6.label: other
6.description: A man may know that nobody has insulted him, but that he has invented the insult for himself...

7.label: rivalry
7.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch blames Pyotr Alexandrovitch for shaking his faith, saying, 'Yes, Pyotr Alexandrovitch, you were the cause of a great fall.'

7.label: rivalry
7.description: Miusov shows contempt towards Fyodor Pavlovitch, saying, 'You defile everything you touch.'

7.label: follower/mentor
7.description: Alyosha is observing Father Zossima and accompanies him, indicating a relationship of respect and guidance.

7.label: mentor/follower
7.description: Father Zossima addresses Alyosha when asking the gentlemen to not tell lies, showing a position of guidance and authority over him.

8.label: Other
8.description: The speaker speaks to Pyotr Alexandrovitch, expressing a desire to communicate and test their compatibility: 'Is there room for my humility beside your pride? I am ready to give you a testimonial that one can get on with you!'

0.label: parent
0.description: The text refers to Madame Hohlakov as the mother of a girl of fourteen, indicating a parental relationship.

0.label: child
0.description: The text mentions the daughter as the child of Madame Hohlakov, implying a child-parent relationship.

0.label: visitor
0.description: The text identifies the old monk as a visitor who sought the elder's blessing, establishing a relationship of visitor to Father Zossima.

0.label: religious connection
0.description: The old monk is noted to seek Father Zossima's blessing, indicating a religious connection or respect for the elder.

1.label: healer
1.description: The 'possessed' woman he knew already. She came from a village only six versts from the monastery, and had been brought to him before.

2.label: parent-child
2.description: Nastasya states, 'I have buried my little son,' indicating her relationship to her son.

2.label: spiritual advisor
2.description: Father Zossima addresses Nastasya as 'Father,' indicating a role of guidance in her pilgrimage.

3.label: parent
3.description: It's my little son I'm grieving for, Father. He was three years old.

3.label: spouse
3.description: I say to Nikita, my husband, 'Let me go on a pilgrimage, master.'

3.label: spouse
3.description: my Nikita has begun drinking while I am away... I’ve done with him.

3.label: spiritual connection
3.description: they say, 'Thou didst give us life, O Lord,' they say, 'and scarcely had we looked upon it when Thou didst take it back again.'

3.label: pastoral guidance
3.description: Therefore you too, mother, know that your little one is surely before the throne of God, is rejoicing and happy, and praying to God for you.

4.label: parent
4.description: The mother mourns for her son, Alexey, stating, 'But he’s gone, Father, he’s gone, and I shall never hear him again.'

4.label: spouse
4.description: Nikita tries to comfort the mother by saying, 'Foolish one, why weep? Our son is no doubt singing with the angels before God.'

4.label: spiritual advisor
4.description: The elder comforts the mother by saying, 'Be not comforted. Consolation is not what you need. Weep and be not consoled, but weep.'

4.label: spiritual connection
4.description: The elder states that the mother's son, Alexey, is 'one of the angels of God' who looks down from there at her.

5.label: spouse
5.description: It is a sin for you to leave him. Your little one will see from heaven that you have forsaken his father, and will weep over you.

5.label: parent-child
5.description: My Nikita, my Nikita, you are waiting for me.

5.label: follower-benefactor
5.description: Dear Father, God reward you, our benefactor, who prays for all of us and for our sins!

5.label: spiritual advisor-follower
5.description: I will remember him, mother, and your grief in my prayers, and I will pray for your husband’s health.

5.label: parent-child
5.description: Her son Vasenka was in the commissariat service, and had gone to Irkutsk in Siberia.

6.label: spiritual guide to seeker
6.description: The peasant woman asks, 'What is it, my child?' showing her need for forgiveness and guidance from the elder.

6.label: spouse
6.description: The peasant woman mentions, 'I had a hard life with my husband. He was an old man. He used to beat me cruelly.'

6.label: confessor to penitent
6.description: The elder provides a space for the woman to confess her sins and seek absolution.

7.label: other
7.description: The Peasant Woman brings sixty copecks to the Priest, indicating a respectful relationship where she seeks his guidance for helping others.

7.label: other
7.description: The Priest expresses gratitude and affection for the Peasant Woman, saying, 'You are a good woman. I love you.'

7.label: parent
7.description: The Peasant Woman refers to Lizaveta as her little girl, establishing a mother-daughter relationship.

7.label: blessing
7.description: The Priest blesses both the Peasant Woman and Lizaveta, indicating a spiritual connection between them.

0.label: Parent-Child
0.description: The lady speaks of her daughter Lise with concern and affection, indicating a parent-child relationship.

0.label: Grateful Student
0.description: The lady is expressing her gratitude to the Elder for healing her daughter, indicating a respectful relationship stemming from a healing session.

0.label: Acquaintance
0.description: Lise shows playful affection and teasing towards Alyosha when she points at him and laughs.

A horrible fury of hatred suddenly surged up in Mitya’s heart: 'There he was, his rival, the man who had tormented him, had ruined his life!'

0.description: Mihail Makarovitch's widowed daughter lived with him, with her two unmarried daughters, grown-up girls.

0.label: attraction
0.description: ...though every one knew they would have no dowry, they attracted all the young men of fashion to their grandfather’s house.

1.label: association
1.description: Pyotr Ilyitch knew for certain that he would meet some of Mihail Makarovitch’s visitors there that evening.

1.label: association
1.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch, the prosecutor, and Varvinsky, our district doctor, were playing whist.

1.label: association
1.description: The unexpected Karamazov case agitated Ippolit Kirillovitch profoundly: 'It was a case that might well be talked about all over Russia' as it relates to Mihail Makarovitch's visitors.

1.label: association
1.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov was sitting in the next room with the young ladies.

2.label: spouse
2.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch’s wife had had toothache for the last two days, and he was obliged to go out to escape from her groans.

2.label: friend
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov had been intending for three days past to drop in that evening at Mihail Makarovitch’s, so to speak casually, so as slyly to startle the eldest granddaughter, Olga Mihailovna, by showing that he knew her secret.

2.label: grandfather-granddaughter
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch Nelyudov had been intending for three days past to drop in that evening at Mihail Makarovitch’s, so to speak casually, so as slyly to startle the eldest granddaughter, Olga Mihailovna.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Pyotr Ilyitch was met with the astounding news that old Fyodor Pavlovitch really had been murdered that evening in his own house.

3.label: spouse
3.description: Marfa Ignatyevna, the wife of old Grigory

3.label: caregiver
3.description: She could never get accustomed to it [Smerdyakov's scream].

3.label: father
3.description: Grigory was muttering incoherently: 'He has murdered ... his father murdered...'

4.label: servant
4.description: Marfa continued screaming, and seeing that her master’s window was open...

4.label: neighbor
4.description: Both mother and daughter were asleep, but they waked up at Marfa’s desperate and persistent screaming...

4.label: guest
4.description: It happened that Foma had come back from his wanderings and was staying the night with them.

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: Marya Kondratyevna remembered that at about eight o’clock she heard a dreadful scream from their garden, and this was no doubt Grigory’s scream...

4.label: relationship to the victim
4.description: Grigory’s scream, 'Parricide!' uttered when he caught hold of Mitya’s leg...

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: They lighted a candle and saw that Smerdyakov was no better, that he was writhing in convulsions...

5.label: master-servant
5.description: Grigory was employed in service to Fyodor Pavlovitch, as indicated by Grigory's fear of not being allowed in by him.

5.label: acquaintances
5.description: Marya Kondratyevna ran to the police station and arrived only five minutes before Pyotr Ilyitch.

5.label: romantic interest
5.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch had a present of three thousand roubles for Grushenka, indicating a romantic connection.

5.label: fearful subordinate
5.description: Grigory expressed fear of going into Fyodor Pavlovitch's house due to his unpredictable behavior.

6.label: other
6.description: Pyotr Ilyitch mentioned that Dmitri Fyodorovitch would shoot himself before daybreak, indicating a concern for his well-being.

6.label: other
6.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch spoke to Pyotr Ilyitch about his intention to commit suicide, which demonstrates a form of communicative relationship.

6.label: other
6.description: The prosecutor displays concern over Dmitri Fyodorovitch's intentions, indicating a professional relationship based on investigation.

6.label: other
6.description: The prosecutor relies on Pyotr Ilyitch’s testimony to understand Dmitri Fyodorovitch's mental state and intentions.

7.label: acquaintance
7.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch did as he was told, preserving his incognito, and giving no one but his old acquaintance, Trifon Borissovitch, the slightest hint of his secret business.

7.label: acquaintance
7.description: Mavriky Mavrikyevitch noticed at once a change in Trifon Borissovitch’s face and voice.

7.label: professional
7.description: The doctor remained at Fyodor Pavlovitch’s to make a post‐mortem next day on the body.

7.label: professional interest
7.description: The doctor was particularly interested in the condition of the servant, Smerdyakov.

7.label: professional colleagues
7.description: The prosecutor and the investigating lawyer distinctly remembered the doctor’s saying that Smerdyakov could not outlive the night.

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Mitya fell on his knees beside her and held her tight in his arms. He exclaimed, 'Grusha, my life, my blood, my holy one!'

0.label: romantic connection
0.description: Grushenka cried frantically, 'Judge us together! Punish us together. I will go with him now, if it’s to death!'

1.label: father-son
1.description: Dmitri Karamazov states, 'I am guilty of the blood of another old man but not of my father’s.'

1.label: servant-master
1.description: The prosecutor mentions, 'You need not worry yourself about the old servant, Grigory Vassilyevitch.'

character_mapping.Grigory Vassilyevitch: Grigory Vassilyevitch, also known as Grigory

1.label: adversarial
1.description: The investigating lawyer addresses Dmitri Karamazov, asking him about the death of his father.

1.label: adversarial
1.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch, the prosecutor, speaks to Dmitri Karamazov regarding the old servant and the accusations against him.

2.label: father figure
2.description: That old man used to carry me in his arms, gentlemen. He used to wash me in the tub when I was a baby three years old, abandoned by every one, he was like a father to me!

2.label: betrothed
2.description: she is my betrothed!

2.label: authority figure
2.description: Excuse me, at this moment it’s quite impossible

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Mitya acknowledges having met Nikolay Parfenovitch at his kinsman Miusov's.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Mitya had been made very welcome at the police captain’s but noticed a change in their relationship with the police captain now frowning at him.

3.label: less intimate acquaintance
3.description: Mitya's acquaintance with the prosecutor is described as less intimate, although he sometimes pays visits to the prosecutor's wife.

3.label: polite acquaintance
3.description: Mitya visits the prosecutor's wife of his own accord and she receives him graciously.

3.label: slight acquaintance
3.description: Mitya had met the investigating lawyer and talked to him twice.

4.label: father
4.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch acknowledges his relationship with Fyodor Pavlovitch by expressing his sentiments about wanting to kill him: 'I wanted to kill him.'

5.label: father
5.description: Mitya shrugged his shoulders sullenly... All the town knows about it—every one knows in the tavern... I beat my father. I nearly killed him, and I swore I’d come again and kill him, before witnesses.

5.label: spiritual advisor
5.description: I declared them in Father Zossima’s cell.

character_mapping.Father Zossima: Zossima, Elder of the Russian Orthodox Church

5.label: adversarial relationship
5.description: I expressed my doubts and sought information from the prosecutor about the murder case.

5.label: legal representative
5.description: ...interposed Nikolay Parfenovitch. So what was it that impelled you to this sentiment of hatred?

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: I considered as simply stolen from me. Yes, gentlemen, I looked upon it as mine, as my own property... for Grushenka, I considered as simply stolen from me.

6.label: other relationship
6.description: You will allow us to note that point and write it down; that you looked upon that money as your own property?

6.label: other relationship
6.description: The prosecutor looked significantly at the investigating lawyer, and had time to wink at him on the sly.

6.label: conflicted relationship
6.description: I couldn’t bear the look of him, there was something in him ignoble, impudent... But now that he’s dead, I feel differently.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Grushenka jumped up, flung up her arms and, with a loud wail of sorrow, rushed out of the room to him, to her Mitya.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Mitya, hearing her cry, trembled, jumped up, and with a yell rushed impetuously to meet her.

7.label: friendship
7.description: Maximov, who was terribly depressed, terribly scared, and clung to her side, as though for security.

7.label: sympathy
7.description: Mihail Makarovitch, who had been absent, came hurriedly into the room, and said in a loud and excited voice to the prosecutor: 'She’s been removed, she’s downstairs. Will you allow me to say one word to this unhappy man, gentlemen?'

8.label: romantic connection
8.description: ...she mustn’t hinder you, must not depress you, or you may lose your head...

8.label: friendship
8.description: ...she’s a Christian soul, gentlemen, yes, I tell you, she’s a gentle soul...

8.label: supportive figure
8.description: ...I took your Agrafena Alexandrovna downstairs myself...

9.label: admiration/thankfulness
9.description: Mitya expresses gratitude to Mihail Makarovitch by stating, 'I thank you for her' and refers to him as 'the heart of an angel.'

9.label: romantic connection
9.description: Mitya declares, 'that woman is the queen of my heart' and acknowledges her willingness to go to death with him, indicating deep romantic love.

9.label: romantic connection
9.description: The woman cries out, 'I’ll go to death with you,' demonstrating her commitment and love for Mitya.

9.label: professional interaction
9.description: Mitya addresses 'gentlemen' and states he is 'entirely at your disposal,' indicating their professional relationship during the examination.

character_mapping.the lawyers: Mikhail Makarovitch and other unnamed lawyers

9.label: professional interaction
9.description: Mitya refers to 'the old police captain' positively and engages in an examination with him, indicating a professional context.

9.label: professional interaction
9.description: The police captain seems pleased with Mitya's statements, which shows a professional acknowledgment during the interrogation.

9.label: professional interaction
9.description: Mitya engages directly with 'the two lawyers,' indicating an interaction based on the examination process.

0.label: friend
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch had from the first felt marked respect for Ippolit Kirillovitch, our prosecutor, and had become almost his bosom friend.

0.label: friend
0.description: Young Nikolay Parfenovitch was the only person in the whole world whom our 'unappreciated' prosecutor genuinely liked.

0.label: interrogated party
0.description: You don’t know how you encourage us, Dmitri Fyodorovitch, by your readiness to answer.

0.label: interrogated party
0.description: You approve, Ippolit Kirillovitch?

0.label: acquaintance
0.description: I pledged them for ten roubles.

1.label: other
1.description: Mitya responds to the prosecutor’s inquiry about his absence and borrowing money.

2.label: unknown relationship
2.description: Mitya Karamazov acknowledges his action toward Grigory, saying, 'I can’t expect you to pat me on the head for what I did to Grigory, for one can’t break old men’s heads with impunity.'

3.label: friend
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch expresses that he wants to look upon Nikolay Parfenovitch as his best friend at this moment of his life, when his honor is assailed.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch is addressing the prosecutor, indicating that their interaction is part of a legal questioning context.

3.label: friend
3.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch expresses dignified approbation toward Dmitri Fyodorovitch, showing respect and a supportive demeanor.

3.label: adversarial
3.description: The prosecutor is keenly focused on Dmitri Fyodorovitch, indicating a formal role in questioning him during a legal process.

4.label: Other
4.description: Samsonov made a fool of Mitya two days before, and Mitya realized by now that he had been fooled.

4.label: Romantic connection
4.description: Mitya began to give a minute account of the agonies of jealousy he endured on Grushenka's account.

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: Mitya expressed jealousy regarding Grushenka and mentioned his despair when he learned she had deceived him.

5.label: family ties
5.description: Mitya ran into his father’s garden indicating a familial relationship with Fyodor Pavlovitch.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Mitya visited Madame Hohlakov and wished to recount an anecdote about her.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Smerdyakov brought Mitya information regarding Grushenka, implying a connection in their actions.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Mitya reflected that Nikolay Parfenovitch and the prosecutor were not worth his telling about his feelings, indicating some acquaintance.

5.label: other relationship
5.description: Mitya expressed disdain towards the prosecutor and implied frustration with him during the investigation.

6.label: father
6.description: Mitya's intention to harm his father is revealed when he mentions he's going to kill Fyodor Pavlovitch by hitting him on the head with the pestle.

7.label: adversarial
7.description: Mitya expresses his frustration with the situation, comparing the prosecutors to hunters: 'I’m a wolf and you’re the hunters.'

0.label: father son
0.description: Mitya describes his father with a mix of fear and hatred, indicating their familial relationship, e.g., 'I ran across the garden to the fence ... and there Grigory caught me, when I was sitting on the fence.'

0.label: romantic interest
0.description: Mitya expresses a longing to know if Grushenka is with his father, showing his romantic feelings for her: 'when he longed so terribly to know whether Grushenka was with his father or not.'

0.label: other relationship
0.description: Grigory catches Mitya as he attempts to escape, suggesting a supervisory or controlling role as well as a level of concern, e.g., 'Grigory caught me, when I was sitting on the fence.'

1.label: parent
1.description: The old man’s lying there now with his skull broken...

1.label: other relationship
1.description: What makes you think that? observed Nikolay Parfenovitch.

1.label: other relationship
1.description: ...no one knew the signals except Smerdyakov, and me...

2.label: son
2.description: Mitya refers to his father, Fyodor Pavlovitch, when discussing the signals, indicating their familial relationship.

2.label: associate
2.description: Mitya and Smerdyakov are mentioned together in the context of the signals known only to them and their father.

2.label: romantic interest
2.description: Mitya acknowledged tapping the signal for Grushenka, indicating a romantic connection.

2.label: interrogator
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch questions Mitya about the signals, indicating his role as a prosecutor or interrogator.

2.label: deceased
2.description: Fyodor Pavlovitch is discussed in the context of the signals he created, indicating his status as a deceased character.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Mitya expresses his thoughts about Smerdyakov, stating, 'I can’t get Smerdyakov out of my head.'

3.label: father-son
3.description: Mitya acknowledges his own relationship to Fyodor, saying, 'But you are your father’s son, too.'

3.label: potential family
3.description: Mitya mentions, 'he’s very likely his son, you know—his natural son.'

4.label: acquaintance
4.description: Mitya inquires about Smerdyakov by stating, 'And what has he told you, gentlemen—Smerdyakov, I mean?'

4.label: adversarial
4.description: Mitya describes how he struck Grigory on the head, indicating a conflict between them.

4.label: antagonistic
4.description: The prosecutor frustrates Mitya during his statement with vexatious interruptions, indicating a tense relationship.

5.label: assailant-victim
5.description: Mitya admits to jumping down to look at the man he’d hurt, indicating an act of aggression followed by concern.

5.label: acquaintance
5.description: Mitya runs to the servant, Fedosya Markovna, with his hands covered in blood, indicating a connection at a moment of crisis.

6.label: other
6.description: Mitya reflects on disgrace and mentions 'that blood—Grigory’s...' indicating a possible guilt or concern related to Grigory.

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: Mitya discusses his feelings, saying, 'the first rightful lover had come back... it was all over for me...' implying his lost romantic interest.

6.label: other
6.description: The prosecutor is engaged in questioning Mitya and exchanging glances, indicating a legal adversarial relationship.

6.label: other
6.description: Mitya has a confrontational rapport with Nikolay, demonstrated by the exchange of glances.

7.label: attorney-client
7.description: Mitya Karamazov is being questioned by Nikolay Parfenovitch, who is trying to ascertain the source of Mitya's sudden wealth.

7.label: opponent
7.description: The prosecutor is involved in the legal proceedings against Mitya Karamazov and is reminding him of the implications of his silence.

8.label: other
8.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch asks Mitya questions and expresses a professional interaction regarding the evidence.

8.label: other
8.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch observes Nikolay's attempts to engage Mitya and expresses that he has not given up hope.

9.label: business acquaintance
9.description: Mitya spoke to Mr. Perhotin, I believe, of having received three thousand from Madame Hohlakov.

9.label: business associate
9.description: Mitya spoke to Mr. Perhotin, I believe, of having received three thousand from Madame Hohlakov.

9.label: respondent to investigation
9.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch reckoned it all up.

10.label: authority
10.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch informed Mitya firmly that it was his duty and obligation to conduct a minute and thorough search

10.label: compliance
10.description: Mitya submitted gloomily; 'only, please, not here, but behind the curtains.'

0.label: antagonistic
0.description: Mitya Karamazov perceives Nikolay Parfenovitch's behavior as humiliating and supercilious, reflecting a power imbalance: 'He treats me not as an officer but as a thief.'

0.label: authoritative
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch issues commands to Mitya, indicating a position of authority: 'We will tell you what to do.'

0.label: colleague
0.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch collaborates with the prosecutor on examining the evidence: 'Nikolay Parfenovitch did not answer... He was busily engaged with the prosecutor in examining the coat.'

0.label: colleague
0.description: The secretary works with Nikolay Parfenovitch in a professional capacity: 'The secretary... called Nikolay Parfenovitch’s attention to the cap.'

1.label: authority
1.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is conducting an examination and questioning Mitya about the blood on his cuff, stating 'Excuse me, what’s that, blood?'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Mitya thinks of Nikolay Parfenovitch as having contempt for him, reflecting a tense relationship: 'He thinks of me as a puppy.'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Mitya expresses indignation towards Mr. Kalganov regarding the clothes: 'Damn Kalganov and his clothes, too!'

2.label: other relationship
2.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch indicates that Mr. Kalganov provided the clothes: 'Mr. Kalganov has kindly provided these for this unusual emergency.'

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov addresses Nikolay Parfenovitch in the context of an ongoing legal examination and shows disdain by not wishing to speak to him.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch is involved in the legal proceedings against Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov and attempts to engage him in discussion regarding the source of the money found on Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov.

3.label: other relationship
3.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov feels disgraced in front of Trifon Borissovitch, indicating a social relationship where Trifon Borissovitch holds some significance in Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov's eyes.

4.label: child-parent
4.description: Dmitri Karamazov states: 'the man who opened the door to my father and went in at that door, he killed him'

5.label: opponent
5.description: Mitya accuses Grigory of lying, stating 'It’s a barefaced lie. He couldn’t have seen the door open because it was shut. He’s lying!'

5.label: impartial investigator
5.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch confirms Grigory's statement, stating 'I have cross‐examined him several times.'

5.label: prosecutor to defendant
5.description: The prosecutor ends the discussion by instructing, 'Confront him with it.'

5.label: witness
5.description: Grigory is referenced as the old man who Mitya wounded, giving a critical statement about the door being open.

6.label: son
6.description: Mitya refers to his father as 'the old man' and 'father,' indicating a son-father relationship.

6.label: servant
6.description: Mitya accuses Smerdyakov of murdering Fyodor Pavlovich, suggesting Smerdyakov's position in relation to the family as a servant.

6.label: acquaintance
6.description: Mitya claims to have heard of the envelope from Smerdyakov, indicating some form of acquaintance or interaction between them.

6.label: servant
6.description: Grigory is implied to be a servant in the household where Fyodor Pavlovich resides.

7.label: other
7.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch's interest in Dmitri's confession is highlighted when he says, 'that every sincere and complete confession on your part at this moment may... have an immense influence in your favor.'

7.label: other
7.description: Mitya is on trial, speaking with the prosecutor, highlighting a confrontational relationship during the court proceedings.

0.label: former betrothed
0.description: I was sent for by Katerina Ivanovna, formerly my betrothed.

1.label: romantic connection
1.description: I’d just come to love another, her, she’s sitting down below now, Grushenka.

1.label: family relation
1.description: she sent for me a month ago, gave me three thousand roubles to send off to her sister

1.label: unknown relationship
1.description: What’s left of it, eight hundred roubles, is in your hands now, Nikolay Parfenovitch.

1.label: official/prosecutorial relationship
1.description: Excuse me. How’s that?

1.label: unknown relationship
1.description: Allow me to inquire, observed the prosecutor at last,

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: The text mentions the appropriation of three thousand roubles belonging to Katerina Ivanovna, indicating a financial relationship tied to their interactions.

2.label: adversarial relationship
2.description: The prosecutor is questioning and criticizing Dmitri Karamazov regarding the appropriation of money, stating that it is discreditable and disgraced.

3.label: romantic connection
3.description: Mitya refers to Katya as someone to whom he owes money and whom he confesses to, indicating a close relationship.

4.label: romantic interest
4.description: I thought then that she was hesitating between me and him.

4.label: father-son
4.description: It was all to do with the old man, my dead father.

4.label: romantic rivalry
4.description: He was always pestering Agrafena Alexandrovna, and I was jealous;

5.label: sibling
5.description: Dmitri mentions, 'I couldn’t make up my mind, I didn’t dare even to tell Alyosha, my brother, about that fifteen hundred.'

5.label: romantic connection
5.description: Dmitri states, 'You may yet not be a thief. Why? Because I might go next day and pay back that fifteen hundred to Katya.'

5.label: other
5.description: Dmitri expresses concern about killing the old servant, stating, 'what has tortured me most during this night has not been the thought that I’d killed the old servant.'

6.label: romantic connection
6.description: I was mean enough for that. But to go to her, to tell her of my treachery, and for that very treachery, to carry it out, for the expenses of that treachery, to beg for money from her, Katya...

6.label: antagonistic relationship
6.description: Surely you don’t think me such an out and out scoundrel as that? You can’t be speaking in earnest?

6.label: implied rivalry
6.description: ...to beg for money from her, Katya (to beg, do you hear, to beg), and go straight from her to run away with the other, the rival, who hated and insulted her...

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Mitya expresses that he might have gone to Katerina Ivanovna to beg for money, indicating an emotional or romantic connection.

8.label: opponent
8.description: The prosecutor is questioning Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov about the missing money and his statements regarding it, indicating an adversarial relationship due to the legal context.

9.label: other
9.description: I took it from her.

character_mapping.landlady: Grushenka (often referred to in relation to her role as landlady)

10.label: romantic connection
10.description: Mitya expresses concern for her, saying, 'Surely she need not be ruined with me? She's innocent, you know... I've been grieving over her all night as I sat with you.'

11.label: friend
11.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch thanks Nikolay Parfenovitch for their honesty and straightforwardness, implying a level of camaraderie and mutual respect.

11.label: friend
11.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch suggests having tea, indicating a friendly and considerate relationship.

0.label: adversarial
0.description: Trifon Borissovitch bears witness against Dmitri Fyodorovitch, showing stern indignation with the accused.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch retorted firmly to Dmitri Fyodorovitch, providing evidence about the money involved.

1.label: other
1.description: Dmitri Fyodorovitch asked to send for Andrey to confirm what he had declared.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch mentioned Stepan as a witness to Dmitri Fyodorovitch's claims about the money.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch referred to Semyon when discussing the witnesses regarding the money Dmitri Fyodorovitch had.

1.label: other
1.description: Trifon Borissovitch mentioned Pyotr Fomitch Kalganov as standing beside Dmitri Fyodorovitch during the time relevant to the discussion about the money.

1.label: other
1.description: Ippolit Kirillovitch observed Dmitri Fyodorovitch's remarks subtly, indicating his psychological analysis of the situation.

2.label: acquaintance
2.description: Kalganov had been meeting Mitya every day for a long time past.

2.label: respect
2.description: He spoke of Agrafena Alexandrovna with reserve and respect, as though she had been a lady of the best society.

2.label: romantic connection
2.description: she had said that she loved him

3.label: antagonist
3.description: Mitya was roused at once and declared that he would not allow the 'scoundrel' to speak like that in his presence!

3.label: antagonist
3.description: Pan Mussyalovitch at once called attention to the word 'scoundrel' and begged that it should be put down in the protocol.

3.label: self
3.description: Mitya fumed with rage.

4.label: transactional offer
4.description: Mitya attempted to buy off Pan Mussyalovitch, offering him three thousand roubles to resign his claims.

4.label: confronter
4.description: Pan Vrublevsky confirmed the statement regarding Mitya's offer to Pan Mussyalovitch.

4.label: defendant
4.description: Mitya was on trial, defended himself against the prosecution's inquiries about the money.

5.label: debtor
5.description: Maximov confessed that he had done wrong, that he had borrowed 'ten roubles in my poverty' from Dmitri Fyodorovitch.

5.label: debtor
5.description: Maximov declared that he was ready to pay the ten roubles back to Dmitri Fyodorovitch.

5.label: companionship
5.description: Old Maximov had, all this time, taken refuge below with Grushenka, sitting dumbly beside her.

5.label: companionship
5.description: Grushenka began trying to pacify and comfort old Maximov.

5.label: association
5.description: Mitya declared that Pan Mussyalovitch would have accepted the money and noted that he might have even gotten a larger sum.

6.label: other
6.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch asked her, hesitating a little, but preserving the most courteous manner, on what terms she was with the retired lieutenant, Dmitri Fyodorovitch Karamazov.

6.label: professional
6.description: Nikolay Parfenovitch was obviously apprehensive of the effect her appearance might have on Mitya.

6.label: professional
6.description: Mihail Makarovitch himself led Grushenka in.

6.label: other
6.description: As she entered the room, Grushenka only glanced for an instant at Mitya, who looked at her uneasily. But her face reassured him at once.

7.label: romantic connection
7.description: Grushenka stated that she had not loved Dmitri but had won his heart as well as his old father’s in her nasty spite.

7.label: jealousy
7.description: Grushenka mentioned that she had seen that Mitya (Dmitri Fyodorovitch) was very jealous of Fyodor Pavlovitch and everyone else.

7.label: financial dependency

2.label: disagree
2.description: Kolya states, 'I often disagree with Mr. Rakitin.'

2.label: friend
2.description: Kolya confides in Alyosha, saying, 'That’s between ourselves, of course, Karamazov; do you hear, not a word to any one.'

2.label: friend
2.description: Alyosha expresses concern for Kolya's character, stating, 'I am only sad that a charming nature such as yours should be perverted by all this crude nonsense before you have begun life.'

3.label: friend
3.description: Kolya expresses feelings of conceit and regrets not visiting Nina sooner, which Alyosha acknowledges by suggesting knowing people like Nina would be beneficial for Kolya.

3.label: friend
3.description: Alyosha observes warmly that knowing people like Nina would have a great effect on Kolya.

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Kolya mentions Nina, saying he likes her and describing her as 'awfully nice and pathetic.'

3.label: acquaintance
3.description: Alyosha encourages Kolya to come often to see Nina, indicating familiarity and a positive view of her character.

4.label: friend
4.description: Alyosha answered warmly, indicating a supportive and friendly relationship.

4.label: friend
4.description: Kolya expresses his concern about Alyosha's opinion, saying he prizes it, indicating a friendship.

4.label: family
4.description: Kolya states, 'I worry every one about me, especially my mother,' indicating a family relationship.

5.label: friend
5.description: Alyosha says, 'You really are not like every one else, here you are not ashamed to confess to something bad and even ridiculous.'

5.label: friend
5.description: Kolya admires Alyosha, saying, 'Oh, how I love you and admire you at this moment just because you are rather ashamed!'

6.label: friendship
6.description: Alyosha says to Kolya, 'you will bless life on the whole, all the same.'

6.label: friendship
6.description: Kolya acknowledges his bond with Alyosha by stating, 'Either we shall be friends at once, for ever, or we shall part enemies to the grave!'

6.label: admiration
6.description: Kolya expresses admiration for Alyosha, stating, 'you treat me quite like an equal. But we are not equals, no, we are not, you are better!'

6.label: affection
6.description: Kolya confesses to Alyosha, 'I loved you awfully. I've been loving and dreaming of you.'

0.label: medical
0.description: The doctor is responsible for the care of the patient, as indicated by his instructions on treatment and recommendations for relocation.

1.label: friend

1.description: Kolya is with Ilusha at his bedside, indicating a bond of support and friendship.

3.label: friend
3.description: 'Will you come yourself?' he cried sharply and angrily to Alyosha.'

2.label: friend

2.label: friend
2.description: Grushenka sent almost every day to inquire after him.

2.label: acquaintance

2.label: friend
2.description: Alyosha, who did not come every day and never stayed long.

2.label: father
2.description: Her old merchant lay seriously ill at this time, 'at his last gasp' as they said in the town.

3.description: Maximov expresses his worthlessness, suggesting a bond where Grushenka's kindness towards him is notable.

3.label: concern

3.label: romantic interest
3.description: Grushenka's discussions about Mitya's jealousy and her reference to looking after him imply a romantic connection.

4.label: financial benefactor

4.label: financial benefactor
4.description: Then Grushenka suddenly felt sorry for them, and at dusk she went round herself to their lodging.

4.label: donor-recipient

5.description: Grushenka notes that Mitya praises Katerina, saying she ordered a doctor, which implies he has feelings for her.

6.description: Alyosha expresses confidence in Mitya's innocence and discusses his situation, showing their friendly relationship.

2.description: Now she is going to follow one of your brothers to Siberia...

7.label: romantic connection

7.label: resentment

2.label: sibling
2.description: Nina pressed her lips to her brother’s for the last time as they bore the coffin by her.

2.label: friend

2.label: friend
2.description: Alyosha showed concern for Nina and her family, ordering the landlady to look after her.

2.label: family/friend

3.label: child

3.description: Alyosha comforts Snegiryov during the service and engages in conversation with him.

4.label: financial supporter

4.label: family

characters.snegiryov: Snegiryov, a man of gaunt frame and shabby attire, reflects the struggles of his existence through his weary countenance, with sunken cheeks and hollow eyes that speak of both despair and a stubborn resilience. His hair, unkempt and graying, frames a face marked by hardship, yet hereto lies a certain dignity that cannot be wholly disguised. His demeanor oscillates between profound sadness and fierce indignation, embodying the moral complexities of Dostoevsky's world. It is his profound sensitivity to injustice that sets him apart, compelling him to stand against the overwhelming weight of societal decay. Like a shadow tethered to hope, Snegiryov remains a poignant reminder of the human condition, battling the frayed edges of poverty while clinging to his innate sense of morality.
characters.father anfim: Father Fydor Pavlovich Karamazov is a portly, disheveled man in his late fifties, with a face that epitomizes both sly cunning and grotesque indulgence. His wiry hair, once dark, is now streaked with gray, standing somewhat tousled, matching the often unruly nature of his temperament. Cool, glinting eyes exhibit a shrewdness that hints at his manipulative tendencies and penchant for moral corruption. Dressed in a threadbare cassock, his appearance belies a life spent reveling in excess and debauchery, yet there lingers an unsettling charisma about him. He oscillates between fatherly affection and conniving self-interest, embodying a complex persona that is as repulsive as it is fascinating, representing the moral decay and existential turmoil of his time.
characters.zossima: In Fyodor Dostoevsky's 'The Brothers Karamazov', the character of Zossima emerges as a man of deep wisdom and profound compassion, marked by a serene demeanor that belies the tumult of the world around him. With a long, flowing beard and gentle, kind eyes that seem to hold the weight of countless sorrows and joys alike, he embodies a spiritual radiance that draws others to him, exuding a warmth that invites confession and healing. His frail physicality, reminiscent of a saintly figure, contrasts sharply with the fervent strength of his convictions, and his every gesture reflects a deep humility, as though he carries the burden of his own failings and the world's suffering upon his shoulders. Zossima's presence is both comforting and unsettling; he speaks with an air of authority that commands respect, yet his true power lies in his unwavering belief in love and redemption, making him a beacon of hope in a world engulfed by existential despair.
characters.nikolai parfenovitch: Nikolai Parfenovitch, a figure ensconced in the shadows of Fyodor Dostoevsky's intricate world, possesses a striking presence that belies his understated demeanor. His tall frame is often draped in a worn but neatly kept coat, the fabric whispering of modesty yet hinting at a care for appearance. His sharp, intelligent eyes, reminiscent of a hawk's keen gaze, dart around with a probing intensity, revealing a mind that never rests in its quest for understanding. There is a certain somberness to his expression, framed by a narrow face and slightly furrowed brow, as though the weight of the world sits upon his shoulders, yet amid this serious demeanor lies an engaging warmth that draws people in. Parfenovitch's voice is soft, almost soothing, yet it carries an earnest conviction that reflects his philosophical inclinations. His character resonates with a profound sense of loyalty and integrity, embodying the moral complexities central to the novel, and his interactions are imbued with a thoughtful contemplation that reveals the struggles of the human spirit. In essence, Nikolai serves as a quiet yet compelling mirror to the existential dilemmas that pervade the narrative, making him an indispensable part of Dostoevsky's rich tapestry.
characters.alyosha fyodorovitch karamazov: Alyosha Fyodorovitch Karamazov, a youthful figure with soft features and gentle eyes that express compassion, embodies the innocence and spiritual depth sought in a tumultuous world. His hair, dark and slightly wavy, frames a face that radiates warmth and sincerity. Clad modestly, his demeanor is humble yet earnest, reflecting a deep inner conviction and a quest for moral clarity. Alyosha walks with a quiet grace, often accompanied by a sense of tranquility that brings solace to those around him. His character, reminiscent of a modern saint, is defined by his empathy, unwavering faith, and a longing for harmony in the midst of familial strife and existential turmoil. His profound ability to listen and understand the pain of others reveals the tenderness and resilience of his spirit, making him a beacon of hope amidst the dark complexities of life that plague the Karamazov family.
characters.ilyusha snegiryov: Ilyusha Snegiryov, a tender and fragile boy of striking innocence, presents a delicate figure, his small stature barely betraying the heartache etched upon his youthful face. His bright eyes shimmer with a profound depth, reflecting a soul marked by both suffering and unyielding hope. His hair, unkempt yet endearing, frames his pale cheeks, while a hint of a smile often flickers across his lips, showcasing his resilient spirit despite the grim shadows cast by his circumstances. Ilyusha's demeanor is imbued with an earnest sincerity; he possesses an innate ability to elicit compassion from those around him, embodying the purity of childhood even amid the harsh realities of the adult world. His unwavering loyalty to his friends, especially to the enigmatic Alyosha, underscores a deep yearning for connection and understanding, making him a poignant representation of innocence in a tumultuous world.
characters.lise alyosha karamazov: Alyosha Karamazov is a striking figure set against the tumultuous backdrop of 19th-century Russia, embodying a serene and gentle spirit that seems to radiate warmth even in the coldest of settings. His youthful face, framed by tousled brown hair, conveys a sense of innocence and purity, contrasting starkly with the moral complexities surrounding him. Deep, contemplative eyes reflect his empathetic nature, hinting at his profound capacity for forgiveness and understanding. Dressed simply, often in modest clerical attire, he appears humble and unassuming, a stark divergence from the flamboyance of his familial ties. Alyosha’s demeanor is marked by an innate kindness, marked by a natural tendency to engage deeply with others, listening intently and responding with compassion—qualities that define his role as a moral compass in the narrative. His unwavering faith and gentle resolve shape the fabric of his character, making him both a beacon of hope and a source of conflict among the Karamazov brothers, capturing the essence of spiritual struggle and redemption that resonates throughout Dostoevsky's masterpiece.
characters.foma fomich: Foma Fomich, a character of notable curiosity in Dostoevsky's 'The Brothers Karamazov', embodies a paradoxical blend of humility and sardonic wisdom. With a slight, stooped frame and unkempt hair that suggests a disregard for personal vanity, he wanders through the narrative cloaked in an air of subdued resignation. His eyes, however, are alive with a piercing intelligence, endlessly questioning the moral fabric of those around him. Foma's demeanor is that of a keen observer; he possesses an uncanny ability to unravel the complexities of human nature with a single, incisive remark. His speech often drips with irony, mingling wit with earnest introspection, making him a reluctant yet essential commentator on the turbulent lives of the Karamazovs. As the embodiment of the common man's struggle with faith and doubt, Foma's presence in the novel serves both as a mirror and a scalpel, cutting through the hypocrisy that pervades the society around him, drawing readers into the depths of existential inquiry.
characters.grigory karamazov: Grigory Karamazov, the loyal servant of the Karamazov family, stands with a frame that bears the weight of years spent in servitude and diligence. His weathered face, lined with the tracks of a hard life, hints at a deep well of wisdom forged from hardship. Grigory's sharp, observant eyes, glimmering with an unyielding loyalty, reflect both the love he holds for his employers and the silent suffering he endures as a witness to their tumultuous relationships. His demeanor, marked by a mix of submission and quiet strength, reveals a man who, while often overshadowed by the Karamazov clan, possesses a deep moral resolve. Clad in humble attire, he carries himself with a grace that belies his lowly status, embodying the conflicts and complexities of a world rife with existential turbulence, mirroring the novel's exploration of faith, duty, and moral struggle.
characters.captain snegiryov: Captain Snegiryov, a figure steeped in a somber nobility, exudes an air of subdued authority, marked prominently by his strikingly gaunt face that bears the weight of countless hardships. His angular cheekbones and piercing, sunken eyes roam the periphery of his surroundings with an intensity that belies both sorrow and a resolute dignity. Dressed in a worn, military-style coat that hangs loosely on his frail frame, he moves with a deliberate calmness, as if each step is both a burden and a defiance of fate. Snegiryov's disposition is one of quiet reserve; he approaches conversations with the measured tone of a man who has both witnessed the folly of human nature and harbored the hope for redemption. His mannerisms, often betraying a hint of vulnerability, reveal a complex interplay of honor, despair, and an unyielding sense of justice, embodying the profound questions of faith and morality that echo throughout Dostoevsky's narrative.
characters.alexei fyodorovitch karamazov: Alexei Fyodorovitch Karamazov, known affectionately as Alyosha, embodies an ethereal blend of youth and depth, with gentle features that reflect his compassionate soul. His soft, expressive eyes glimmer with an understanding beyond his years, hinting at a inner tumult and spiritual longing. Often described as slight of build, his demeanor is imbued with a quiet strength and serene confidence, which draws others to him like a moth to a flame. Dressed simply, often in modest attire, Alyosha moves through the world with an air of humility, yet his presence is resplendent, radiating kindness and warmth. A devoted brother and a novice monk, he is guided by a fervent moral compass, embodying the deeply held values of faith, love, and forgiveness in a world overshadowed by turmoil and existential doubt, leaving an indelible mark on those whose lives he touches.
characters.mikhail snegiryov: Mikhail Snegiryov is a figure marked by an air of somber dignity, his appearance a reflection of his inner turmoil. With dark, unkempt hair and deep-set eyes that hide a turbulent spirit, he carries the weight of his struggles almost visibly upon his shoulders. Clad in threadbare clothing, his frame is both lean and worn, suggesting the toll that hardship has taken on him. Mikhail's demeanor oscillates between despondency and a fierce sense of integrity; he is principled yet often overwhelmed by the despair of his circumstances. His voice, when he speaks, is often hushed, tinged with a tragic introspection, revealing a man caught in the throes of moral confusion and the search for redemption, making him a poignant embodiment of the novel's existential themes.
characters.father zosima: Father Zosima, a figure of serene wisdom and profound kindness, carries an aura of both humility and spiritual authority that captivates all who encounter him. His gentle face, framed by a halo of white hair, exhibits a softness that belies the fervent intensity of his convictions. The deep-set, wise eyes radiate compassion, often glimmering with a hint of sorrow for the human condition. Clad in the simple robes of a monk, his demeanor exudes an unassuming grace, inviting confessions and revelations from the troubled souls around him. Zosima's voice, when he speaks, resonates with a melodic calmness, embodying a deep philosophical understanding of suffering and redemption. Every gesture reflects his unwavering commitment to love and forgiveness, making him a beacon of hope amidst the moral struggles and existential dilemmas woven throughout the fabric of Dostoevsky's narrative.
characters.alexei fyodorovich karamazov: Alexei Fyodorovich Karamazov, known as Alyosha, stands as a beacon of compassion and spiritual depth amidst the tumultuous struggles of the Karamazov family. With gentle features that mirror his thoughtful demeanor, his soft brown hair falls just above his kind, expressive eyes that radiate sincerity and warmth. A slight build complements his almost ethereal presence, evoking the image of a young monk rather than a worldly man. Clad in simple yet modest attire that speaks to his humility, Alyosha is often seen with a serene smile, offering solace and understanding to those around him. His unwavering faith, fueled by an innate goodness, drives him to serve as the moral compass of the narrative, embodying the theme of redemption in a world marred by conflict and moral ambiguity. His character exudes a rare blend of innocence and wisdom, marked by a deep empathy for both the suffering and the joy of others, making him a luminous figure against the darker elements of human nature pervasive in Dostoevsky's work.
characters.alyosha fyodorovich karamazov: Alyosha Fyodorovich Karamazov stands as a beacon of spiritual innocence and moral fortitude amidst the tumult of his family’s tumultuous existence. With his gentle demeanor and soft, earnest eyes that reflect a depth of compassion, he embodies the essence of youthful idealism and sincerity. His physical appearance, characterized by a youthful countenance framed by tousled dark hair, hints at both vulnerability and strength. Clad often in humble clothing, he possesses an unpretentious air that endears him to all he meets. Alyosha’s character radiates warmth and a profound sense of empathy, allowing him to connect deeply with others, and his unwavering faith serves as an anchor in a world rife with conflict and despair. His quiet courage and selflessness make him a pillar of hope within the chaotic Karamazov family, embodying the struggle between faith and doubt that permeates Dostoevsky’s narrative.
characters.miusov: Miusov is a man of striking contradictions, his tall, gaunt figure often lost within the tattered elegance of his attire, reflecting both his noble lineage and his perhaps careless attitude towards wealth. A sharp, narrow face punctuated by piercing blue eyes conveys an air of keen intellect, yet his expression frequently betrays a hint of cynicism, as if he stands aloof and slightly amused by the follies of those around him. His hair, dark and unkempt, adds to his air of carelessness, while his manner, at once brusque and contemplative, demonstrates a man deeply entangled in the moral inquiries that beset his family. Miusov navigates his surroundings with a restless energy, embodying the turmoil of a society on the brink of change, his dialogues laced with a mix of arrogance and self-doubt that reveals the complexity of his character and the weight of expectation thrust upon him.
characters.grigory kutuzov: Grigory Kutuzov, with his stooped shoulders and weathered visage, embodies the burdens of fate and responsibility that weigh heavily upon him. His gray hair, perpetually tousled, frames a face etched with deep lines of worry and contemplation, revealing a soul worn by the struggles of life. Kutuzov’s eyes, a striking shade of pale blue, mirror both a profound wisdom and an underlying sorrow, casting a knowing gaze upon those around him. He possesses a quiet, steadfast demeanor, often speaking in a low, measured tone that encapsulates his profound sense of duty and loyalty. Despite his unassuming appearance, there’s a resilience in his posture—the way he stands, facing adversity with a quiet strength.
